utterance.speaker: Ethan Hartig
utterance.content: Amber.

utterance.speaker: Karen Hartig
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Amber’s a stripper name.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Find me one stripper named Amber Hartig. Or not, okay. Non-stripper names, okay. Desiree? Bambi? Candy cane?

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Max. Maxine. Max Hartig is a cute name, isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: If you’re a professional boxer, maybe.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Can you believe we made this little creature?

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: I know, it’s incredible.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: It’s the most amazing thing we’ve ever done.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: I almost ran the marathon last year.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: If we’re lucky you won’t inherit your daddy’s sense of humor.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Hello! Say hi to Bear!

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: She hasn’t even eaten anything; what is she spitting up?

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Well, honey, we can’t bug them –

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Just –

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Okay, okay.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Sorry, it’s our first kid, we’re both a little panicky I guess.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Yeah. Second time in an hour?

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: You lived underwater for nine months, you’d have a lot to spit up, too.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Is something wrong?

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Eh, a little lethargic.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: We didn’t think –

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: She’s hot.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Is she, uh –

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: What’s happening?

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Baby’s seizing! Get the crash cart!

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: What’s, what’s, what’s, what’s wrong?

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Can I get some help in here?!

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Oh, oh God! Is she all right?

utterance.speaker: A nurse
utterance.content: IV access?

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: No, ativan.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Soap doctor
utterance.content: MRI results are back.

utterance.speaker: Soap patient
utterance.content: And?

utterance.speaker: Soap doctor
utterance.content: It’s what we expected. The accident caused serious damage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s amnesia.

utterance.speaker: Soap doctor
utterance.content: I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Soap patient
utterance.content: I just can’t believe it.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Enjoying our lounge, House?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I just came in to get milk for my coffee, which you’re out of.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Flat.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Sparkling.

utterance.speaker: Kubisak
utterance.content: So, the Hartigs?

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Their baby gets a fever.

utterance.speaker: Kubisak
utterance.content: Wait, don’t tell me. Their kid had a seizure.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Yep. The parents, of course, start freaking and I have to deal with that for an hour.

utterance.speaker: Kubisak
utterance.content: Like it was your fault.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: She was perfect when I delivered her. If you want to blame someone, blame the pediatrician.

utterance.speaker: Kubisak
utterance.content: So, how’s the kid now?

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Bowel obstruction, she’s under observation, she’ll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Kubisak
utterance.content: Pediatrician’ll take all the credit.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exhibit A: Baby girl Hartig. Term baby, 42 hours old. Went into seizures 6 hours ago, brought into the intensive care, diagnosed with obstruction of the small bowel.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m still amazed you’re in the same room with a patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: People don’t bug me until they get teeth. Exhibit B: Baby boy Hausen. Another term baby, 48 hours old. Brought into the NICU before the Hartig baby: fever of unknown origin, 101 degrees, trending upwards.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Wow, that is amazing. You hung out in the OB/GYN lounge and heard about two sick babies. It’s eerie.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t touch that.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: All right…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We have an infection spreading in the hospital.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: These kids have totally unrelated illnesses.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They fell sick within four hours of each other. They had the same delivery rooms, maternity rooms are neighboring, so transmission’s possible. They have the same symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The Hartig girl has a bowel obstruction. No matter how close their beds are, I’m pretty sure kids can’t share a blockage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What does bowel obstruction on a chart indicate?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, normally, I’d say it indicates a patient’s bowel is obstructed, but I’m pretty sure you have some deeper truth to impart –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It means that some random doctor of indeterminate skill thinks that the patient’s bowel is obstructed.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Okay, you’re upset because they threw you out of their lounge.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look at the x-ray. It’s a normal gas pattern.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You want, I can get you a key to the oncology lounge.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Air. Air in the colon.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We’re getting TiVo.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If it’s air, no bowel obstruction.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Even if it is air, it could have been there before the obstruction.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Something’s infected both these infants.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And you’re the only one who put this together because…?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because I’m the only one who looked at both kids. I want them isolated; I want the maternity ward shut down.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Because you’re better at reading an x-ray than a radiologist.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Radiologists always over-read babies’ x-rays, especially if they’re asked to rule out a pathology. He read into it what he wanted.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Which is exactly what you’re doing. You’re finding a cluster because you think it’s interesting to find a cluster. Two… plain old sick babies would bore you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See, this is why I don’t waste money on shrinks, ‘cause you give me all these really great insights for free.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Shrink. If you would consider going to a shrink, I would pay for it myself. The hospital would hold a bake sale, for God’s sake.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We have an epidemic!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Two sick babies is very sad, but it doesn’t prove an epidemic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How many do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get up! We’re going hunting.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: For what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wabbits.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hi. Bye. He’s screaming, he’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Good looking baby.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Oh, sorry, wrong room.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ll see you later.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: 12 rooms, that’s it?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yep. We’ve definitely checked the whole floor. Good news, no epidemic.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tragic, huh?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Overflow rooms, third floor.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This imaginary infection has spread to the next floor?

utterance.speaker: Judy
utterance.content: We were just going to call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did he get hot all of a sudden?

utterance.speaker: Judy
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Excuse me! Hi. Intake sent you up here?

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: Yeah, my wife’s contractions are less than –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah, Intake messed up. I’m very, very sorry. Nurse Alpret will arrange for an ambulance to take you to Princeton General.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: Wha –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The maternity ward is temporarily closed.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: We have to leave?!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yes, I am very sorry.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: Why are you doing this?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’ll be there very, very soon. Happy now?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. But I am interested.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Three sick babies, and a fourth showing early symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How bad?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Spiking fevers.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: BP’s plummeting. They’re barely able to keep systolic up; at this rate, they’ll be dead in a day.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Where did this come from?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Two delivery rooms, four different maternity rooms, no common personnel and no common equipment.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, there’s gotta be something in common.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. That would be the difference between an epidemic and a coincidence.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m putting a team together. We’re going to start swabbing.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What’s she gonna swab? Every respirator, sink, vent, drain in the entire hospital? That’ll take months.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: A needle in a haystack.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s worse than that. We don’t even know what’s the needle we’re looking for.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Then why’d you let her go do it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because the hospital’s her baby, and her baby’s sick. If she doesn’t solve this soon, her head’s going to explode, and I don’t want to get any on me. So let’s figure out what’s in the haystack. Differential diagnosis, people.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Parasite.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Spreading too quickly.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Next?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Virus?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Kids are too sick, and the blood tests show no lymphocytosis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And they’re not responding to a cycle of avirarapovirin. If it’s some other virus, we’ll never find it in time, anyway.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which leads us to bacterial infection. It’s not responding to broad-spectrum antibiotics, so we’ve got something resistant. The usual suspects.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: MRSA. It’s always MRSA in hospitals.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maybe a contaminated food or water source? Psuedomonas.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: VRE?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: H-Flu.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, those are the big ones. Cultures will take 48 hours, might as well be post-mortem. We’ll start them on Vancomycin for the MRSA and Aztreonam for the rest. Let’s get MRIs, check for abcesses or some occult infection. I’ll be in the clinic. Grab me if you find something important. Or unimportant.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We did a MRI on all the babies, and unfortunately, we didn’t find anything, so we’re starting him on the strongest antibiotics we’ve got, and we’re hoping that that’ll take care of it.

utterance.speaker: Judy
utterance.content: But he’s so tiny.

utterance.speaker: Kim
utterance.content: How sick is he?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: His fever’s up to 103.5 and his blood pressures 80 over 40.

utterance.speaker: Judy
utterance.content: Um, how bad is that?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Ah, it…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It, it’s low. The heart needs to circulate the blood. If it’s weak, oxygen isn’t getting to the liver, the kidneys, the brain.

utterance.speaker: Judy
utterance.content: Um, I have to ask you something.

utterance.speaker: Kim
utterance.content: Judy –

utterance.speaker: Judy
utterance.content: No, no, Kim. Let me. Um, I had a cold last month, and I told the doctors about it, and –

utterance.speaker: Kim
utterance.content: Honey, this has nothing to do with you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Kim’s right. Your son was born healthy. He caught the infection after his birth. There’s no reason to think he got it from you.

utterance.speaker: Judy
utterance.content: But you don’t know, I mean – You don’t know how he got sick.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Pretty standard question: how sick is my child? You couldn’t answer it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I answered.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You rattled off numbers! BP, O2 stats.… That’s not what they need to know.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What they need to know is the future. Got a magic 8-ball?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, just eight years of medical training. Look, I realize it’s tough to break bad news to family –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Not as tough as hearing it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And I guess being the poor guy dying is toughest of all?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No. It’s easier to die than to watch someone die.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, we’re checking the vents, it could be airborne. Somebody get the sinks, too, and underneath them.

utterance.speaker: Med Student with the Tie
utterance.content: I’ll get it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How many med students have you got swabbing the decks?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh, what else are they going to do? It’s not like they’re delivering babies.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Find anything yet?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Ah, yeah. About half the antibacterial gel dispensers are empty or broken.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That’s bad. And diagnostically, completely insignificant.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, if the staff can’t wash their hands, it’s no wonder an infection has spread. Hey, tie clip!

utterance.speaker: Med Student with the Tie
utterance.content: Sorry?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We have an epidemic in this hospital and your tie is becoming a Petri dish. Put on a tie clip or take the damn thing off.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lift up your arms. You have a parasite.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Like a tapeworm or something?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lie back and lift up your sweater. You can put your arms down.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Can you do anything about it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Only for about a month or so. After that it becomes illegal to remove, except in a couple of states.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Illegal?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t worry. Many women learn to embrace this parasite. They name it, dress it up in tiny clothes, arrange playdates with other parasites –

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Playdates…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It has your eyes.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: But… that’s impossible.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I assume you weren’t getting your period. Maybe that should have give you an inkling.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: But I’m on this birth control implant…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I know. I saw the scar on your arm.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: …and my doctor said I might not get any periods at all if it was working.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mm hmm. Interestingly enough, you also don’t get any periods if it isn’t working, which is why you were supposed to get regular pregnancy tests. I’m going to send a nurse in here to schedule your prenatal care. You’re due in about five months, so start planning the shower.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Um, Doctor? Please. Me and my husband wanted to have a kid soon, but… oh, God. Like four months ago we had this really big fight. He moved out. I did something stupid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: One-night stand?

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Ex-boyfriend.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ll schedule you a paternity test, too.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: I can’t let my husband know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does the old boyfriend look like your husband?

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Yeah…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then just have the kid. He’ll never know. The most successful marriages are based on lies. You’re off to a great start.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, you look cheery. What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The Hartig and Chen-Lupino babies. Their kidneys are shutting down.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And the urine tests show no casts.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which means the antibiotics are causing the kidney failure.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re the nephrologist. Which one did it? We’ll take ‘em off that one. Don’t tell me both Vancomycin and Aztreonam can –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: They both can cause this. There’s no way to know which one it is. No test.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We can’t take them off the antibiotics. They’ll die of the infection.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If we leave them on both the antibiotics they’ll die of kidney failure.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So, we take our best guess, then. Which drug’s causing the kidney failure?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s like I said: it’s always MRSA in hospitals. Take ‘em off Aztreonam.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I still think it’s the pseudomonas. I vote to take them off the Vancomycin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s no point in guessing. Take one kid off Vancomycin and the other off Aztreonam.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: They have the same disease, you want to give them different treatment?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What the hell are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Theraputic trial to find the cause of the infection.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We have four sick kids, at least. Who knows how many more haven’t started showing symptoms yet?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We have a duty to these two!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If these two have different reactions we know how to save the rest.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So you’re condemning one of these kids to die based on random chance.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I guess I am.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So, you’re going to flip a coin? That’s how you decide which baby lives?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can I borrow a quarter?

utterance.speaker: Hospital Attorney
utterance.content: Do you want to get sued, lose your license, House? Well, generally I’d applaud that, but my job is to protect this hospital, so I strongly advice you to come up with a medical rationale why Baby A should get Medicine X and vice-versa.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Whoa, whoa, whoa, hold on there, Slick. We didn’t all go to law school. Your advice is that I should use medical reasons to make medical decisions? Hmm, that’s not going to be as easy…

utterance.speaker: Attorney
utterance.content: Any medical justification. Doesn’t need to be a good one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, Hartig sounds Jewish, so does Aztreonam, so we’ll take the Hartig kid off Vancomycin, how’s that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You can’t experiment on babies.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Doctors experiment all the time.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: On adults. With their consent.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine. I’ll get the parents’ consent.

utterance.speaker: Attorney
utterance.content: Their informed consent. They have to know the other kid is getting a different treatment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry, can’t do that. It’d be unethical for one patient to know about another patient’s treatment.

utterance.speaker: Attorney
utterance.content: They have a right to know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If they know, they won’t consent; that defeats the whole purpose.

utterance.speaker: Attorney
utterance.content: That’s their right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Two more babies have just become symptomatic. I defer to your legal wisdom: which takes precedence? Six dying babies or a missing consent form?

utterance.speaker: Attorney
utterance.content: You can’t do it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do what you think is best.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your daughter’s kidneys are shutting down…

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Your son’s kidneys are failing.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: …so we’re going to take her off the Aztreonam.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’re taking him off Vancomycin.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: But, uh, but what made her sick in the first place?

utterance.speaker: Kim
utterance.content: What do you think is causing it?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It seems to be a germ called pseudomonas.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We think it’s MRSA. Methicillin-Resistant Staph Aureus. It’s a very resistant form of a very common bacteria.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’re hoping the Aztreonam will clear it up.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Vancomycin is the best treatment for MRSA, so we’re gonna keep giving it to her.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Right. Is it gonna cure her?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your child is very sick. You need to know that. This is a ‘hail Mary’ pass. It might cure her, it might not.

utterance.speaker: Judy
utterance.content: So, so that’ll cure him?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We’ll know in 24 hours if it’s working.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What did you tell them?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I told them the truth.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: They seemed relieved. You tell them how sick their son is?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I explained what was going on.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Alison, their baby’s dying. If the parents weren’t in tears when you left, you didn’t tell them the truth.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That’s not how I see it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Do you want them blindsided? Want them coming up and saying “My God, my baby died, why didn’t you warn me?”

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So now it’s about worrying about them yelling at us?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, it’s about getting them prepared for the likely death of their child.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If their son dies tomorrow, do you think they’ll give a damn of what I said them today? It’s not going to matter; they’re not going to care; it’s not going to be the same ever again. Just give those poor women a few hours of hope.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Dr. House! Dr. House, this is my husband, Charlie.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who told you where my office was?

utterance.speaker: Charlie
utterance.content: Jill, come on, he obviously doesn’t want us bothering him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ooh, I was trying to hide it.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Look, Doctor, this is about the mono you said you thought I had…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The mono?

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Yes. You know, shouldn’t Charlie be tested? You know, the test. The blood test.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right. Yeah, I’m sorry, I sometimes forget patients, I thought you were this idiot who doesn’t know how to use birth control.

utterance.speaker: Charlie
utterance.content: I can’t have mono. I don’t even feel sick or anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s very often the first sign. Call my office in the morning, I’ll schedule him for bloodtests.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Thank you!

utterance.speaker: Charlie
utterance.content: I’m not even tired.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Find anything yet?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, just some baby formula being stored under a sink with a dripping faucet.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Tap water contamination. You thinking pseudomonas infection?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I was. I wasted a couple of hours chasing it down, but of course the formula hasn’t been anywhere near the babies.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Huh.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Whatever idiot stored them there –

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: All right, we’ll figure it out! Just… just calm down.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I am calm.

utterance.speaker: Med Student without Tie
utterance.content: Aw, could –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I warned you. I did that calmly.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Is she any better?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Her fever’s been stable the last hour.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: We’re not going to make it, are we?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Sorry?

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Me and Ethan. Our next-door neighbor, their little boy died in a car crash and she and her husband split up, like, four months after the funeral. It’s just, uh, what always happens, right?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Um, what happens to patients after they leave the hospital, I don’t know, but… try not to get ahead of yourself.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: How long?

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: I don’t know, it just started.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Pulse? Fluid wide open. Do we have an arterial line?

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Not yet.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Let’s get a BP. You can’t come in here.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Is my baby dying?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Mrs. Hartig –

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Is she dying?!

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Ma’am, you’ll have to leave.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s not your baby!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Fenlay, BP 60 over 20.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Heart rate’s 180.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: They’ve got it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Still dropping. 50 over 10.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Can’t hold BP with three pressers? We’re losing pulse.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: V-fib.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Shut the blinds.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Charging. Clear.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Still v-fib.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Charging. Clear. Charging. Clear.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Still v-fib.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Charging. Clear. Charging.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chase. Time of death: 6:57 PM. The Aztreonam doesn’t work. Double-cover all the other babies with Vancomycin.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ll do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cameron, you tell the parents. Tell them their child probably saved five lives.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: But Chase should –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chase is busy.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You’re the attending.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Make sure she does her job.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I asked you to make sure she does her job, not do it for her.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She froze up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She felt sorry for the parents so she shut up. You felt sorry for her so you opened your mouth.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She has a problem.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, she needs to deal with it. If you hadn’t bailed her out, she would have done it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Great, then she wouldn’t have slept for two weeks. Maybe she should be thinking about a different specialty. Lab work, research?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, what is it?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The Hartig baby. She’s getting sicker, too. The Vancomycin isn’t working, either.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Vancomycin doesn’t kill it. Aztreonam doesn’t kill it. What the hell is this?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s a super bug.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It could be VRSA.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: There’s only been two reported cases of it ever in the United States.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: One of the kids, the Hausen baby, had a skin rash. It could be scalded-skin syndrome which would be a sign of VRSA.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Then these kids are dead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is our fault. Doctors over-prescribing antibiotics. Got a cold? Take some penicillin. Sniffles? No problem. Have some azithromycin. Is that not working anymore? Well, got your Levaquin. Antibacterial soaps in every bathroom. We’ll be adding Vancomycin to the water supply soon. We bred these super bugs. They’re our babies. Now they’re all grown up and they’ve got body piercings and a lot of anger. On the other hand, maybe antibiotics had nothing to do with it. Did you notice how low his BP was at the end? Even with three pressers?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Heart damage?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go home. There’s nothing more you can do tonight.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Baby boy Chen-Lupino. Time of death 6:57 PM Thursday, December 2nd, 2004.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is a cross-section of the Chen-Lupino boy’s myocardium. Fibrosis, lymphocydic infiltrates.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There was no sign of lymphcytosis in the blood tests.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, well, we all had plenty of good reasons to think bacterial. Nobody is scolding you. Unfortunately, all of those clever reasons were wrong. It is a virus infecting their hearts.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’re screwed. We can’t chase down a virus; there’s a thousand possibilities.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We could run gels, antibody tests.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A thousand of them? The kids don’t have enough blood.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chase, you’re the intensivist. How many could we do before we risk exsanguinating the kids?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You’re talking vials, not stick tests? I wouldn’t take more than five or six.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, so we have to narrow the thousand viruses down to six. Now, the autopsy’s shown us what the virus does. So, let’s go. What do we know?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ribavirin and encyclovir don’t knock it out.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Cross out the herpes viruses.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Also adenovirus. What else, what else? Keep talking.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Well, it, it only seems to hit children. The mothers aren’t sick, so…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No toxoplasmosis, no rubella. Cross out the entire TORCH Syndrome.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You didn’t find any lung damage?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: None of the paramyxoviridae.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cardiac scarring, people.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: CMV?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Enteroviruses, too, I think.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Echo 11.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Influenza A.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Influ A. Yes. And? I’m putting RSV down as a yes. That makes eight.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Eight vials of blood is pushing it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pushing it, but we love that! Get the antibody kits, start testing the sick kids.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: All right, I’ll start looking into whether there are any antivirals for these eight.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wait a second. The, the kids on the floor who didn’t get sick. Are any of them still in the hospital?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: They got moved to the fifth floor. But they’re probably all checked out by now.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, the Lindpert boy had a bit of jaundice. He should be checking out today.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want to test his blood, too.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: ‘Cause we need all the information we can get. The healthy kid can be our control group.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’ll just tell his parents he can’t check out because he has the smallpox.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: All done, all done.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What did we get?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, the sick babies all tested positive for Echovirus 11.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And CMV, and parvovirus B19.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Three viruses?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What’s weirder, the healthy kid we tested: he’s positive for Echovirus 11 and CMV antibodies as well.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They’re infants. They have their mother’s blood, their mother’s antibodies.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So we just learned nothing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh-uh. We have half the picture. The healthy kids survived because their mothers’ antibodies saved them.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The mom had CMV in the past she’d have the antibodies for them, the kid would be immune from it. So we test the sick kids’ moms for Echovirus, CMV, and parvovirus.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And whichever they don’t have the antibodies for, that’s what’s killing their kids.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’ll test the mothers.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Echovirus 11. It’s an enterovirus. It lodges in the intestinal tract.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Enteroviruses cause diarrhea and flu-like symptoms in adults, maybe a rash, but for newborns it can be deadly. It’s damaging her heart.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: Well, is there anything you can do?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Viruses are more difficult to treat than bacterial infections. We still haven’t found a cure for the common cold.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: So, there’s no vaccine, or…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There’s a company in Pennsylvania developing an antiviral. It got positive results in a lab setting and we managed to get our hands on it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Imagine not being able to touch your own baby. Can I get your guys’ help with something?

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Sure.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Your daughter, her –

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Maxine.

utterance.speaker: Karen
utterance.content: That’s her name.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We need someone to hold Maxine off of the bed while the nurse changes her sheet.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Sure. {They enter the room, now in scrubs, and hold Maxine.]

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, Foreman? Got a minute?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So, pulmonary resistance is stabilized for the two kids, but BP’s still –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No news, then. How’s Cameron?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dr. Cameron?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure. Let’s start with her, and move on to all the other Camerons we know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Sorry, I’m just not used to you asking about someone’s well-being.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can understand how the question would surprise you. I don’t quite get how it would confuse you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why do you want to know?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why do you want to know why I want to know?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Just curious.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Me, too.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You don’t get curious.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m the most curious man in the world.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not about trivialities.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, then, this must not be trivial. How is Cameron handling everything?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Just fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great, glad we talked.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your husband is definitely the source of your “mono”.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Oh, wow. Oh, thank God. Wow, I’m going to be a mom. Whoa, heh heh. Thank you so much; I gotta get you a gift or something.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sometimes the best gift is the gift of never seeing you again.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Okay, all right! But, Dr. House, you’ve been so awesome. I mean, I really, totally trust you. Do you think you –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: -- could do the prenatal?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Or deliver the baby?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That would be no.

utterance.speaker: Jill
utterance.content: Okay!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Chase, take a look at this.

utterance.speaker: Ethan
utterance.content: Oh, God. It’s good news.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, it’s great.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They all gone?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Hartigs are checking out right now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You look tired.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Thanks.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s no wonder. You’ve had a hard time the last couple of days.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And you haven’t?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not like you. Anyone who’s that awkward either has no experience around death or too much, and I’m pretty sure it’s not the former. Chase told me about that idea you had: the parents holding the baby. Where’d you get that? Did you lose someone? Did you lose a baby?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You can be a real bastard.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Unfinished business?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m in the haystack.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Ah, because now you know you’re looking for a needle.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If I tell you to “let it go,” it won’t make any difference, will it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Enteroviruses are spread by humans. Fecal, oral… could be respiratory secretions, though.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So, Cuddy got stool samples from the whole staff. Just wait until they come back.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That won’t do it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The shedder, whoever he is, is so virulent, Cuddy must have noticed him.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hmmm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And the babies didn’t share any common personnel. That’s what’s weird.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah. That’s what’s weird.

utterance.speaker: Old woman
utterance.content: Can I help you?

utterance.speaker: Soap patient
utterance.content: You saved my life.

utterance.speaker: Soap doctor
utterance.content: I just ran some tests. Your will and determination are what saved your life.

utterance.speaker: Soap patient
utterance.content: I know who I am now.

utterance.speaker: Soap doctor
utterance.content: Yes, you do. And I know who I am as well.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: Hey, seriously, man, you’re not supposed to be here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m performing a delivery.

utterance.speaker: Kubisak
utterance.content: You are.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Patient whose prenatal care I’ve been handling. Just checking her out a couple of minutes ago. Of course, I’ll need one of you two guys to supervise.

utterance.speaker: Lim
utterance.content: When’s she due?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Late March.

utterance.speaker: Kubisak
utterance.content: That’s five months from now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank God these chairs are comfortable.
